text: Bottle. Chestnut clear ale with a thick offwhite head. Nose is heady, with "off" bready notes. Doesnt taste off though, and is surprisingly light. Some nice breadiness, a little caramel/toffee. A proepr british bitter with a bit of a twist.

Bottle at home, from Royal Mike Whisky. It pours deep amber with a decent off-white head. The nose is bitter-sweet, juicy, biscuit, toffee, fruit cake and nut. The taste is bitter, piney action, toffee, baked goods, biscuit and some candied peel with a dry finish. Medium body and moderate carbonation. Great balance and high drinkability. Very drinkable.
Both slightly hoppy and malty aroma. Thin head. Cloudy appearance, but maybe I poured some sediment from the can. Tastes very nice, citrusy bitter and hoppy.

Bottle from beer 52 pours a great deep Amber minimal lacing and head. Aroma is sweet caramel, lovely balanced malty tones, American hops adding unobtrusively to the whole event, taste is golden syrup, light hops. Mouthful is smooth and delightful. Great job from the folks at Heriot Watt.

Aroma: caramel, bread malts, lots of grain. Appearance: clear amber, small, creamy, white head. Taste: light sweet. Palate: grain malts, some caramel, light floral hops coming up, remains quite light, but delicate. Overall: very nice ESB, excellent aroma and palate, well-balanced. Pint at Cloisters Bar, Edinburgh.

This is a very refreshing example of an Amber ale of American style, perhaps more so than esb. The nose is not particularly distinguished, but it has a very nice palate of Orange and biscuit malt. The finish is gently hoppy. I am quaffing this on a got evening, it hits the spot nicely, so much more sophisticated than your average lager.

A fine example of a hoppy ESB with the American hops adding a citrus zing over the solid malt flavours. Really good "English" ale!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

33cl bottle from Beer52.com. A slightly hazy amber pour with a fast fading white head; sweet orangey fruit aroma; rather thin malty body with a pleasant earthy bitterness; and some caramel to finish. Pleasant to really too thin.
Excellent malty nose, plus a good dose of funky hops. Palate is old fashioned bitter, finish is long and pleasingly hoppy
On Cask at the southern deep amber colour pine aroma with citrus notes flavour is juicy orange some grapefruit with sweet carmel balance nice beer but unusual for bitter style more ipa style

Cask dispense at the Hanging Bat Beer Cafe. Deep red with off white head. Massive piney aroma, grape fruit and orange. Taste is hoppy up front, pine and orange with some biscuity malt. Fully bodied and goes down easy. Id say it has a lot more in common with amber ales listed on this site than bitters.

Can from Appellation Wines. 
Appearance - deep amber with a decent head. 
Nose - toffee and oranges. 
Taste - loads of oranges with big biscuit note and toffee. 
Palate - close to medium bodied with a creamy texture and a long dry finish. 
Overall - great example of the style.

330ml can from Appelation Wines, Dalry - cheers Ash! Pours hazy golden amber with a thin ring of white head. Aromas of red fruits, toffee malt. Taste is malt, light herbal, almost menthol note, then light citrus and pine. Medium body, light sweet caramel on the finish. Quite a bit going on.
Cask at SRAF 2015. Juicy hops and sweet malt with an oily texture. Pretty decent.

Peach and mango on nose. Moderate carbonation and body, fruity sherbet, grapefruit, low bitterness, quite sweet. Brief finish. Refreshing
Cask, hand-pulled, SRAF15, Corn Exchange, Edinburgh (9 Jul 2015), nice grassy, malty aroma, clear golden amber, no head, caramel, grassy, very sweet, oily, very nice

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2015 Bottle from Drinkmonger and cask at The Other Place - review is a combination of the two. Clear amber body with an off-white head. Light lacing. Aroma of orange, mango and overripe pineapple. Flavour of orange marmalade, mandarin and a peppery finish. Thin to medium body with an oily texture. Light fizz. The juicy hops work really well. A very good, hoppy Bitter.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Cask at SRAF... Copper.. Thin white lacing... Soft orange toffee fruit nose... Bitter oily orange.. Soft bitter fruits 

Bottle at home... Copper.. Thin tan lacing.. Soft sweet toffee caramelised fruits nose... Soft sweet fruits... Soft toffee malts... Dry fruits.. Soft toffee.. Bitter oil fruits.. Light metalic 3.2

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2015 Can from Oddbin. Pours cloudy orange. Nose is caramel, floral, plenty of citrus hops. Taste is citrus, decent hops and malts, light caramel, light bitterness. Quite hoppy bitter. Not bad at all.
Keg at Teviot. Pours clear amber, nose is floral, toffee, grassy, taste is similar, chewy, crisp.
